Award.AwardTitle: Pa-231 and Th-230 in the Western North Atlantic: Disentangling the Effects of Boundary Scavenging and Ocean Circulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Boundary scavenging is the increased adsorption of radionuclides such as thorium-230 (Th230) and protactinium-231 (Pa231) onto particles in ocean margin areas; however, this process is not well understood. The sediment record of 231Pa/230Th has played a crucial role in interpreting past ocean circulation and sediment transport, and therefore, it is important to constrain the boundary scavenging component of these radionuclides. A researcher from Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution plans to develop a numerical model of ocean circulation, sediment transport, and particle scavenging to determine the processes that control the distribution of these two radionuclides in the Western North Atlantic. This study is particularly timely, since model observations will be tested using data collected as part of the ongoing GEOTRACES program. The results of this research will be incorporated into coursework taught at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology-Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution Joint Program in Oceanography, and the project will involve a graduate student. The computational codes will be disseminated in such a way that they can be useful to other researcher in the ocean sciences community.

Current understanding of boundary scavenging processes on the cycling of particle-reactive elements in the ocean is poor. Simple box models are generally used, which cannot account for the boundary scavenging effects. This research will apply a high spatial resolution, regional model, taking into account ocean circulation, sediment transport, and chemical scavenging. The model will be used to constrain the processes that control oceanic distributions of Th-230 and Pa-231, two radionuclides the ratios of which have been extensively used in studying past ocean circulation. The model will be compared to GEOTRACES data for comparison and to help refine the model, placing the project in line with two of the overriding goals of the GEOTRACES program. The results from this project will be widely applicable to global ocean biogeochemical models that must account for boundary scavenging.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Boundary scavenging is the enhanced deposition, in ocean-margin sediments, of particle-reactive substances originating from the open ocean. In this project, observations and models have been analyzed and applied to study the boundary scavenging of thorium-230 (Th-230) and protactinium-231 (Pa-231), two naturally-occurring particle-reactive radionuclides which have found various applications in oceanography. Emphasis has been placed on the western North Atlantic, where evidence for effects of boundary scavenging and ocean circulation on the distributions of Th-230 and Pa-231 both in the water column and in surface sediments are apparent. This project was motivated by two goals of GEOTRACES, an ongoing international program to study the cycle of trace elements and isotopes in the ocean: (1) to characterize more completely the processes regulating the oceanic distributions of Th-230 and Pa-231; and (2) to enhance understanding of the processes that control sediment Th-230 and Pa-231 records, from which changes in ocean circulation during past climate changes have been postulated. The project has involved scientists with different background and experience as well as (under)graduate students who have worked on different aspects of the project.

The main results of this project are the following:

1) Previous studies have documented that the Th-230 and Pa-231 activities in deep waters (below 2000 – 4000 m) are systematically lower near the western North American margin than elsewhere at similar latitudes in the North Atlantic. At least two processes could account for the relatively low activities observed near the western margin: (i) intensified scavenging in particle-rich layers overlying the seafloor (benthic nepheloid layers, or BNLs), which can have thicknesses of a thousand meters or more and are often observed in the western basins, and (ii) the ventilation of the western basins with Th-230 and Pa-231 poor waters emanating from the deep western boundary current. In our project, we found that the relatively low Th-230 and Pa-231 activities observed in deep waters near the western margin stem more likely from intensified scavenging in BNLs than from ventilation by Th-230 and Pa-231-poor waters from the western boundary. Thus, particle scavenging, not ocean circulation, appears to be the primary mechanism regulating the distributions of both radionuclides in the studied area.

2) Previous studies have postulated that the reflection of internal waves (the deep water analogues of surface gravity waves) on continental slopes can generate bottom shear stresses that are large enough to resuspend sediments and hence lead to the formation of nepheloid layers. The highest shear stresses are expected to occur when wave reflection is “critical”, i.e., when the direction of wave energy is equal to the slope of bottom topography. In our project, we found that stations showing large dissolved activity minima and large particulate activity maxima near the bottom of the water column do not occur in regions of high critical slope occurrence: topographic slopes that are critical with respect to the reflection of the M2 (semi-diurnal) internal tide appear mostly confined nearest to the margin. Thus, we found no evidence that sediment resuspension produced by M2 internal tides reflecting on topographic slopes could be responsible, via intensified particle scavenging, for the strong radionuclide anomalies observed near the bottom in the western North Atlantic.

Overall, the results of our project point to benthic nepheloid layers as potential sites of intensified particle scavenging near continental slopes and rises. Anomalies in the rates of removal of particle-reactive elements such as thorium and protactinium in BNLs compared to rates in surrounding waters could result from the relatively large concentrations and (or) the peculiar chemical composition, of the particles which inhabit BNLs. Indeed, as shown in this project and in a previous project, analyses of Th isotope and particle data collected at stations away from the western boundary where the influence of water transport on property budgets makes data interpretation in terms of Th cycling and particle processes difficult, indicate that the rate of Th adsorption onto particles in North Atlantic waters varies with both bulk particle concentration and particle type. As also shown in this project, the reflection of internal waves (M2 tide) does not seem to provide an important mechanism for sediment resuspension and near-bottom intensified scavenging along the western segment of GA03 between the New England continental shelf and Bermuda. Other processes responsible for the formation and maintenance of BNLs, such as episodes of strong abyssal currents (“benthic storms”) in areas of high surface eddy kinetic energy, may provide, via sediment resuspension, more important mechanisms for the Th-230 and Pa-231 deficits observed in deep water along the western North American margin. The interpretation of sediment records of the Pa-231/Th-230 ratio from this area, and from similar areas characterized by BNLs, may need to consider the effects of processes taking place in the deepest part of the water column, particularly if these processes lead to the fractionation between the two radionuclides.
